The way we buy wine is broken.

We believe there’s a better way forward. Buy direct, support a future for independent wineries, and #DrinkBetter.

The way we buy wine is broken.

The Winery
The Distributor
Restaurants & Retail Shops
You!

What the Big Guys don't want you to know.

It Hurts Diversity in the Industry

Between 1970 and 2019, one third of existing family-owned wineries in Napa & Sonoma were sold to corporate entities. 14% closed entirely.

Source: Jordan Winery

It Causes Huge Markups

Distributors and Retailers each expect a ~30% cut. oIf you buy a bottle for $40, they winery only receives $15. And because the price increases operate off percentages,markups are even bigger with higher quality wines..

Source: Wine Folly

It Limits Quality

The average Retail Shelf is 98% big brands who are industrially producing "bulk wine" where flavorings and chemicals outshine the wine itself.

Source: Cornell Law

MOST IMPORTANTLY...

The Big Guys often exploit the idea of small, family-owned wineries, hiding behind a narrative that perpetuates the problem.

Currently,76% of all wine sold in the U.S. is produced by just 10 wineries - despite the fact there are over 11,000 wineries in existence.

Source: Jordan Winery

These Big Guys may own and control smaller winery entities that seem like they’re still family-owned, or use white label practices (hello, two buck chuck!) to create snappy, on-trend bottles that are nothing more than overpriced alcoholic grape juice - not wine.

What you may not realize - your grocery store mass-produced wine could have up to 72 ingredients other than grapes.

These wines come from huge swaths of land (particularly central California and Provence), with “terroir” that’s barely suitable to grow anything at all. To cut on costs, these bulk wines are often made from rotten or low-quality grapes, under-ripe fruit, or even wine by-products. Then, to hide or “fix” this quality issue, the wine is typically treated like a chemistry experiment or lab formula. Mass-produced laboratory yeasts mask subpar grapes by adding unnatural aromas to the wine and speeding along fermentation, wood chips are used to add an oaky flavor and cut costs when oak barrels are too expensive, chemicals and dyes are added to chase the desired color, all to achieve the same, standard (read: boring) taste year-after-year.

When we buy wine made by these conglomerates, it puts small, family-owned wineries out of business, & perpetuates the negative cycle.

Buy direct and #DrinkBetter

Sign the pledge

Here at Vinebase, we believe there’s a better way forward – buy direct & support a future for independent wineries. When you buy direct, you have the chance to know your producer and get the real-deal information behind every bottle you buy. Plus, it subverts the system and helps them thrive by supporting their bottom line, instead of paying for pointless middlemen.

At Vinebase, we believe every direct purchase has the power to make a difference.

Here's how we do it:

Pricing should be fair & transparent.

With Vinebase, wineries get 100% of the proceeds of each sale. We only charge wineries a flat transaction fee of $2.95.

Support people, not conglomerates.

The impact is that wineries make 5-7x the profit, and you get higher quality wine for the price.

Quality wine should be a given.

A better wine industry starts with you.

Together, we can change the way we drink wine and support small businesses along the way.

Here are three easy steps to #DrinkBetter:

Shop your values - find wineries that support the same things you do. Whether that’s climate-conscious wineries, women-led wineries, minority-led wineries, or something else, Vinebase makes it easy to discover wineries that align with your values.

Buy direct - buy wine directly from wineries’ websites, their tasting rooms, or using Vinebase. When you order through Vinebase, 100% of the profits go directly to the winery.

Tell your friends - most people are unaware of the challenges faced by small wineries just to survive. They also don’t know that the wines they’re drinking from the Big Guys might contain large amounts of chemicals and be mass produced! Tell them to #DrinkBetter and think about the wine they buy.
